JOSEPH HALL
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in these articles - I saw Piggott, but not the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. He told me he was going to leavethat Saturday night, and told me to take these things, and put into my box; I thought they had a better right to be there than in Mrs. Grove's room: we had lived together for three months - he made me leave my service, and come and live with him.

MARY GROVES
re-examined. They did not live together; the prosecutor is a baker, and used to sleep a few hours, and then go to work - the prisoner had left her service, and I took her in out of charity.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

968.
BENJAMIN GUILLIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of February , 2 coats, value 30s., and 1 hat, value 5s. , the goods of
William Walter
.

WILLIAM WALTER. I lost two coats, and a hat on the 18th of February, from my kitchen, in Earl-street. Kensington
; my wife told me they were gone - I had seen one coat safe on the day before, which was Sunday.

ANN WALTER
. I am the wife of William Walter. The prisoner had a coat lent him three weeks ago, to go to his father's, but he brought it back again; he told me on the Sunday he was going to his father's, and asked for the coat; I said my husband would be angry, and I would not lend it him; I went into the back kitchen, and he took it off a nail; when I returned into the kitchen, the prisoner, the coat, and the hat, were gone - there was no one else in the house but my little girl.

WILLIAM BENNETT
. I am a constable. I met the prisoner about a fortnight afterwards in High-street; he came up to me, and surrendered himself; he said, "Have you not got a warrant against me?" I said, "A warrant against you! No;" he said, "My name is Guillis:" I said, "You are my prisoner;" he had this old coat and this hat on - he said he had sold the other coat.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I have always been in the habit of wearing these things.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined One Month .

969.
MARY HAGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of March , 1 shift, value 1s., and 1 frock, value 1s. , the goods of
John Barand
.

NANCY BARAND
. I am the wife of John Barand; we live in Little Earl-street, Seven-dials
. I was in my parlour on the evening of the 6th of March; I heard a noise, went out, and found the prisoner at the foot of the stairs - I had known her some years; these things laid at her feet - they had been taken off a line; I asked what possessed her to take them; she said if I would forgive her, she would never do the like again, and fell on her knees.

JOHN GREEN
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I went there to inquire for a person, who I was told lived there, and as I came down stairs this lady came out - she brought down these things, and said I had taken them off the bannisters.
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Confined Three Weeks .

970.
CAROLINE MEYERS
was indicted for
stealing on the 11th of March , 1 sheet, value 3s. , the goods of
Robert Bryant
.

MARY BRYANT
. I am wife of Robert Bryant, we live in Ironmonger-row, St. Lukes
. On the 10th of March the prisoner came and left her box at our house and went out - she came again next day to lodge there; she went out at eight o'clock that night, very quick - I went to her room and missed a sheet and pillow-case; she returned in half an hour with a basket, I sent for the watchman, and asked her for the sheet, she said, "You need not bother about a trumpery sheet, I'll get you another tomorrow."

WALTER CASTELLO
. I am a watchman. I took the prisoner - who said, she was in distress; I found the duplicate on her, and got it out.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 40.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Weeks .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

971.
EDWARD BAKER alias EDWARD REILY
, was indicted for
stealing on the 26th of February , 269 lbs. weight of lead, value 44s., the goods of, and belonging to
George Dawson
and
Francis Child
, and fixed to a certain building of theirs .

GEORGE DAWSON. I am in partnership with Francis Child, we are wine-merchants
, and have several houses at Islington
; our servant is in possession of them for us.

JOHN GARDENER
. I am a milkman, and live in George-place, Holloway. I keep my cows in a field adjoining Mr. Dawson's premises - I went there about seven o'clock in the evening, on the 20th of February, and heard something on the houses; I went up to the cows - returned, and heard the noise again; it appeared to be on the slates of the house - I heard it several times, and at nine o'clock I spoke to the watchman - we went to the houses; I stopped in front, while he went round - the prisoner and another person came down from inside one of the houses - the other got away; I followed the prisoner for near a mile, and near the New North Bridge; I called for him to be stopped, and he was stopped - I had never lost sight of him; I am certain he ran from the house where I heard the knocking - I went on the roof after he was secured and found five pieces of lead weighing more than 200 lbs. rolled up, it was quite fresh cut.

ROBERT ALLEN
. I am a watchman. On this night I saw the prisoner running without his shoes, pursued by Gardener - I stopped him, and took him to the watch-house.

WILLIAM FLANNAGAN
. I am a watchman. Gardener came to me - I went to the house with him, and heard somebody on the roof; I saw the prisoner and another person come down. they both ran away from the back of the house - we followed; and the prisoner was secured - I was not near enough to swear to his face; I went on the roof by a ladder - there were no stairs; I found five rolls of lead which I saw matched, it corresponded exactly.

GEORGE HARPER
. I found a pair of high shoes, about twenty yards from the back of the premises; they fit the prisoner - there is a bunnion on his right foot, which corresponds with a mark on the right shoe.
Prisoner's Defence. I had been to Barnet; I fellsleep, and my shoes were taken off my feet at the foot(Highgate-hill; I got up walked on, and was taken.
GEORGE HARPER. The prisoner gave this letter to a person to put into the post, it was stopped. - (read.)
To Mrs. Payne, at Mr. Dixons, Blacksmith, James-street, Bethnal Green.

DEAR SARAH, - I am sorry to inform you I am in trouble, in a charge of stealing lead, and am at Hatton-Garden; if you will go to Mr. Hardens and inform them, and ask them if they have got a pair of his old ones to lend me. I shall be at Newgate or Clerkenwell; I hope you will not take it to eart; do not forget Edward Riley; I have gone by the ame of Edward Baker.'
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

972.
GEORGE BROWN
and
ISAAC CLAPHAM
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of March , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
William Henry Deedes
, from his person .

CLAPHAM
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Life .

MR. WILLIAM HENRY DEEDES. I am a Government officer at the board of Commissioners . On the 1st of March, at three o'clock I was opposite St. James' Church, Piccadilly
; I had a handkerchief in my coat pocket - I did not miss it till the officer produced it; the prisoner was then about two yards from me - there was rather a crowd as the Welch children were going to church.

THOMAS THOMPSON
. I am an officer. On the 1st of March, about half-past two o'clock, I was in Piccadilly, and saw the prisoner attempting several people's pockets; I saw them close on the prisoner - Clapham took something from his pocket; I seized him, and he dropped it immediately - Brown had covered him; I had followed them from Gray's-Inn-lane with the procession.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you mean to say you saw Brown touch any pocket? A. No.

DANIEL REARDON
. I am an officer. I was with Thompson and saw the prisoners together - Clapham tried several gentlemen's pockets; the prisoner covered him - they were in company together; as the prosecutor came along they closed upon him - Clapham took the handkerchief and was handing it to the prisoner, we took them both.
Cross-examined. Q. Had Brown touched it at all? A. No; I have made enquiry about him, he is not known to the officers at all.(Property produced and sworn to.)
BROWN'S Defence. I was going on an errand; I saw the procession and got up by the church - the constables told the mob to stand back, and they took me.

BROWN -
NOT GUILTY .

973.
SIDWELL HALEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of March , 1 bag, value 2d.; 1 half-crown, and 2 penny-pieces, the property of
Elizabeth Wickmill
, from the person of
Jane Brown
.

JANE BROWN. I am fourteen years old, and live with my mother. On the 31st of March, at seven o'clock in the evening, I was going along with my cousins; the prisoner and three other girls, came up to us; the prisoner left the others, came up, and asked us for a penny; I had none - my cousin had a halfpenny, and I had one; we put them together and gave them to her. I had never seen her before; she then asked for another penny, I said I had no more of our own: she said she knew we had, and that it was to make up three quarterns of gin, and we should have some. I said we never drank gin; she said she would never let us go clear, if we did not give it to her - she put her hand down my bosom and tore the beads off my neck; she threw them at me, and said, "You may have them again." I had a bag of money down my bosom, I took it out, and held it tight in my hand - she took my hand, forced it open, and pulled it out; my cousin asked her for the money, she took and hit her in the eye, and gave her a dreadful blow - she began to run; I called Stop thief! and she was taken; she gave my bag and money to another girl. I am sure she is the girl who took it - there were two half-crowns and two penny pieces in it; they belonged to Elizabeth Wickmill.

ELIZABETH BROWN
. I am fifteen years old. I was with Jane Brown, and in Duke-street, Manchester-square
, I saw the prisoner come and take the purse; I asked her to give it up - she struck me in the eye and ran away; my cousin called Stop thief! nobody stopped her - I then called out and she was stopped. She gave the money to another girl, who got away.

GEORGE PONDER
. I saw the crowd, and took the prisoner in charge.
Prisoner. I leave it to the mercy of the Court.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Life .

974.
JAMES MATTHEWS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of March , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Robert John Parker
, from his person .

ROBERT JOHN PARKER. I am a clerk . On the 17th of March, I was in Museum-street
, at nine o'clock in the evening, I left a jerk at my pocket, and missed my handkerchief; I saw the prisoner close to me, and accused him of it - he denied it: I called the watchman, and he ran away - I cried Stop thief! and he was taken, without my losing sight of him.
Cross-examined by Mr. CLARKSON. Q. Before he ran away, did he not offer to be searched? A. No, it was dark, the lamps were lighted.

DANIEL HONE
. I live in Castle-street. I was in my shop, and heard a cry of Stop thief! I looked out, and saw the prisoner passing; I went after him, and two men stopped him - he dragged them across the street, to Mr. Yardley's area, and laid down; I then took him to a light, where he was searched - but nothing found on him; he struggled very much - we found the handkerchief in the area.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you lose sight of him? A. No; he was taken five yards from my door - I am a constable, and took him to the watch-house.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had been on an errand.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .

975.
JAMES JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of February , 1 watch, value 4l. , the goods of
John Cargill
.

JOHN CARGILL. I am a mariner , and belong to the Truewhich lay off Hermitage-stairs; the prisoner was engaged on board that vessel. On the 28th of February, I sent him on shore with my things to wash; he did not return - I went down and missed my watch from a drawer in my cabin; I had put it there about eight o'clock that morning; he was found at the Crooked Billet, public-house, with two women.

GEORGE DEVERELL
. I am an officer, and took him in charge. I heard two women had been with him at the Crooked Billet - I went there and took them; the duplicate of the watch was found there, under the seat where he had been sitting.

ROBERT LINWOOD
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Ratcliff-highway; the prisoner pawned this watch, on the 28th of February.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I met a young man, and we went to have some beer. I heard the Theatre had fallen down. went to look at it; then went to another house, and was taken.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

976.
ANN McINTYRE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of February , 1 pair of sheets, value 8s.; 1 blanket, value 3s.; 1 bolster, value 3s.; 1 pillow, value 2s.; 1 looking-glass, value 2s., and 1 candlestick, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Samuel Howard
.

SAMUEL HOWARD. I live in Leg-alley, Long-acre
. On the 3d of February, the prisoner took my second floor front room, at 5s. a week; she left me in ten days without notice, and I missed this property - I found her on the 25th; she said she had pawned my things and intended to redeem them, when she got the money - she told us where they were pawned; we went, and found they had been redeemed - I have not recovered them.

WILLIAM OXLEY
. I am a constable. On the 25th of February, I took the prisoner, and found on her three duplicates, not relating to this property; she told me where she had pawned the things, but they had been taken out.

PHILIP EATON
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in High Holborn. The prisoner pawned a sheet on the 5th of February, it was redeemed on the 15th.

CHARLES WILLIAMS
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned a pillow on the 5th of February, and redeemed it by an affidavit, on the 20th.
The prisoner put in a written defence, pleading distress.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Seven Years .

977.
GEORGE TURNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of April , 1 rule, value 1s., and 1 saw, value 3s. , the goods of
Edward Hill
.

EDWARD HILL. I am a carpenter . On the 2d of April, I was at work in the North-road, Islington
; I went to dinner at twelve o'clock, leaving my tools in the front parlour; the house was not finished - when I returned I missed these tools; the prisoner is a stranger.

THOMAS KIRKWOOD
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Brick-lane, Old-street. I have a saw, pawned on the 2d of April, by the prisoner. I believe; but am not quite certain - this is the duplicate I gave for it.

JAMES TAYLOR
. I am a constable, and took the prisoner about four o'clock, on the 2d of April, and found this duplicate of the saw on him.(Saw produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I met a young man, who asked me to pawn the saw.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Three Months .

978.
JOHN TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of February , 1 round frock, value 5s.; 2 pairs of stockings, value 2s., and 1 shirt, value 2s. , the goods of
Elijah Ventham
.

ELIJAH VENTHAM. I live at Hounslow
. I lost these things on the 26th of February, out of my box, which was in the loft, at Mr. Woodwards, where I live; it was about seven o'clock - I was feeding a team of horses at the door, and heard a noise in the left; I went and looked up, and saw the prisoner coming down; I asked what he did there, he said he went there to lay down - I asked what he had got under his frock; he said, his shirt - I took it out, and it was this property of mine; he was a stranger - he struggled, but I called for help, and he was secured.

WILLIAM KEEN
. I live at Hounslow. Ventham called for assistance; I went up and took the prisoner, and saw these articles taken from him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I had come out of the country; a man stood by the horse-trough - I asked him where I could lay down, as I was in distress; he took me up to the loft, gave me the things out of the box, and said if I took them to Hounslow, they would tell me where to find him - and he would give me 1s.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Seven Years .

979.
MARY WELCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of March , 2 dishes, value 1s.; 1 plate, value 1d.; 3 knives, value 6d., and 3 forks, value 5d. , the goods of
William Bacon
.

WILLIAM BACON. I live in Portpool-lane
. On Sunday evening, the 23d of March, between seven and eight o'clock, I had been serving in my shop; I went out of the shop door to the private door, and met the prisoner coming out of the passage; I took hold of her, and asked what she had got; she dropped a plate which broke, and said, "It is from real hunger" - I took her back, and found these other articles in her pocket; they had been taken from my washhouse - she threatened to destroy herself.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 59.
Confined Two Years .

970.
GEORGE RANDALL
and
GEORGE TERRY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of March
, 28 bottles of port wine, value 3l., and 2 gallons of gin, value 1l. , the goods of
George Mills
; and
WILLIAM WARD HOBBS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .
There being no evidence but that of an accomplice, which was unconfirmed in any particular, the case was not proceeded in.
NOT GUILTY .

981.
DAVID DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of February , 1 watch, value 1l., 1 seal, value 5s.; 1 watch-key, value 3s., and 1 ring, value 2s., the goods of
Michael Dibly
, from his person .

MICHAEL DIBLY. I work for Messrs. Stringer and Co. On the 10th of February, about ten o'clock at night, I was at the Three Crows public-house, City Road
; I cannot say whether the prisoner was there: I had been there about two hours; six or seven people were in the taproom; I pulled out my watch about eight o'clock, and Eliza Morris, who was there, wanted to look at it; she took it, and in a few minutes I enquired for it; she said she had given it me back; she afterwards went out - I went out and gave her in charge - I had not noticed what she did with it: she was tried here last Session; I received a blow from Cooper, who has been tried.

JOHN KETT
. I belong to the Guards. I was at the house, and saw Dibley, Morris, and Harding there; Cooper was not there - the prisoner sat next to Morris, who had the watch some time in her hand, and then laid it down by the prisoner, who took it up and gave it to Harding; he put it into his bosom, and went out; Davis followed; Dibley then went to the bar for an officer to take the girl; the prisoner was taken to the watch-house; I am sure he is the man who had the watch.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me in the room before ten o'clock? A. Yes: I had come from Ware that day.

GEORGE WILMOT
. I was at the watch-house when the complaint was made - I knew the prisoner, and on the Tuesday following I went and took him; I told him it was for a watch; he said, "I may thank Cooper for this" - he afterward said, "I admit I was in the room; but I had nothing to do with the watch" - the watch was returned to the prosecutor at the office by some girls.

THOMAS STOCKS
. I was with Wilmot - the prisoner was discharged, but we were ordered to take him again.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not in the tap-room, but in the parlour, and heard a scuffle; I went out, but knew nothing of it.
NOT GUILTY .

982.
ROBERT DIXON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of March , 1 half-crown, 1 shilling, and 2 farthings, the monies of
James Squires
, from his person .

JAMES SQUIRES. I live with a tailor in New Kent-road. On the 2d of March, between three and four o'clock; I was looking at the ruins of the Brunswick Theatre
; there were a great many people there; I felt the prisoner's hand coming out of my waistcoat pocket, where I had this money; I caught hold of him, and asked him for my money: the officer got it from him. I lost a half-crown, a shilling, and two farthings: the shilling dropped; I took it up, and gave it to the officer.

HENRY HILLIER
. I was at the ruins of the Theatre, and saw the prosecutor there; he accused the prisoner, who was close to him, of stealing his money - I saw the prisoner put his hand behind him, and put some money into his coat pocket; I could not see what but something dropped.

THOMAS JOSEPH WEST
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found a half-crown in his pocket.

JAMES GLEDBURY
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner attempt several pockets before he went up to Squires - I went up, seeing a scuffle - Squires picked up a shilling and a farthing, and gave them to me.
Prisoner's Defence. I had this half-crown and three halfpence in my pocket - this gentleman put his hand into his pocket, he let his money fall, and charged me with it.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Life .

983.
JAMES MALONEY
was indicted for
embezzlement .

PETER GRAHAM
. I am assistant to
John Graham
, of High Holborn. The prisoner was his porter , and had a yearly salary; he was authorised to receive money when he delivered goods; he never accounted for 2l. paid by Mr. Whitehouse; which he should have done when he returned, or at all events on the same day. When he returned he said Mr. Whitehouse had sent out for change, but fearing he might be detained too long he was to call again for it.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Did he not say he had paid Welch? A. Yes; he said so the next morning.

HENRY HOLLAND
. I am a clerk to Mr. Whitehouse, of Thavies Inn. I was out when the parcel was brought, but the prisoner called about ten the next morning, and I paid him 2l. on Mr. Graham's account.

JOHN BURRELL WELCH
. I am cashier to Mr. Graham. The prisoner never paid me this money; it is my duty to receive it - when it was enquired about he said he had given it to me, but I am sure he did not.

Cross-examined. Q. How many errors have you made in the last year? A. I cannot say; I have made a great many - the prisoner left in consequence of this accusation - he came back next morning, saying he was uneasy about it, and desired to have it investigated - he went before the Magistrate.

JOSEPH HEALEY
. I am in Mr. Graham's employ; it is my duty to receive money in the absence of the cashier; the prisoner never paid me this 2l.

WILLIAM HOTSON
. I am a clerk to Mr. Graham; the cashier accounts to me every evening, but never gave me this 2l. - the prisoner wished this to be fully investigated.
NOT GUILTY .

984.
THOMAS BUNN
was indicted for
embezzlement .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

985.
WILLIAM ATTERSLEY
was indicted for
embezzlement .

GEORGE AVELING
. I am an oilman , and live in Gloucester-street, Queen-square. The prisoner was my porter and received money for me; Mr. Harrison is a customer of mine; he lives in Spring-garden-terrace.

CATHERINE ROBERTS
. I live with Mr. Harrison; the prisoner used to bring goods from Mr. Aveling; I paid him 19s. 8d. on the 12th of March, on account of his master, and he gave me this receipt. (read.)

MR. AVELING. He should have given me the money directly he came home; I never received this - Mr. Harrison pays his bills every Wednesday, and as it had stood over two or three weeks, I said to the prisoner, "How is it, Mr. Harrison has not paid his bill?" he said he was out of town - I am certain he never paid me the money.

THOMAS BENTLEY
. I am shopman to Mr. Aveling.On the 17th of March I told the prisoner I was going to call on Mr. Harrison, as master was not satisfied about it: he then said he had received the bills, and what should he do about it.

JOHN LIMBRICK
. I took him into custody, and found 21s. 6d. on him.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he did not intend to defraud his master of the amount
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Transported for Seven Years .

986.
WILLIAM BELFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of March , 2 lbs. of tobacco, value 7s. , the goods of
Joseph Ward
.

BENJAMIN LORD
. I am a Bow-street patrol. On the 26th of March, at a quarter-past seven in the evening, I met the prisoner between the Elephant and Castle and Newington Church; he had something in his jacket; I thought it was wrong, and looked at him; he set off running, and threw down this pracel - I pursued and took him; Shepherd took up the parcel of tobacco, and by the permit we found the owner.

JOHN SHEPHERD
. I was with Lord - his evidence is correct; I picked up the parcel.

JOSEPH WARD. I keep a shop at Tottenham, Middlesex
. This tobacco is mine, and was lost from my counter; I did not miss it till the officers brought it; I should think from the manner I was engaged that it was taken about six o'clock in the evening.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

987.
WILLIAM WARREN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March , 1 bolster, value 7s. , the goods of
John Buckel
.

JOHN GROVES
. I am a watchman. I stopped the prisoner in Bartholomew-square at eight o'clock in the evening of the 18th of March, with this bolster under his arm; he said he had bought it in Finsbury-market.

JOHN BUCKEL. I am a broker , and live in Old-street
. This is my bolster, and was taken from a chair at my door- I never saw the prisoner.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that he was intoxicated, and met a person in Finsbury-market, who sold him the bolster.

JOHN GROVES
. He was sober, and was running as fast as possible.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

988.
GEORGE ROSE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of March , 1 coat, value 4s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 3s. , the goods of
John McKeon
.

JOHN McKEON. I am a labourer , and live in St. Pancrass
. The prisoner lodged in the next room to me, with his mother. I lost my coat and trousers on the 11th of March - my door was not locked.

ROBERT MILTON
. I am shopman to Mr. Sowerby, a pawnbroker, of Whitechapel. On the 11th of March the prisoner pawned this coat and trousers, in the name of John Mack.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A woman advised me to take some wood out of the yard on the same day.
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Judgment Respited .

989.
MATTHEW PLOMER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of March , 1 stew-pan, value 7s. , the goods of
William Taylor Bell
.

JAMES TERRY
. I am a patrol. I stopped the prisoner in Cow-cross on the 5th of March, with this stew-pan under his arm, in a cloth; he said he had bought it for 2s. in Spitalfields.

RICHARD MILLEN
. I was at the watch-house when the prisoner was brought in; he said he bought the pan in Crispin-street, for 2s. - I detained him; he then said a boy gave it to him.

WILLIAM TAYLOR BELL
. I keep the Admiral Benbow, public-house, in Golden-lane. The prisoner used to come to the tap, and talk with my boy - this pan is mine; he said at the office that my pot-boy had given it to him: my boy absconded directly the officer came to the house; the pan was in my kitchen. I lost the key of the kitchen three or four days before.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in the house - this boy asked me to go and sell an old pan for him; he gave it to me; I was to sell it for old copper, and he was to give me what he thought proper.
GUILTY . Aged 42.
Confined Three Months .

990.
JOHN GIBSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of March , 1 oak-joint, value 2s. , the goods of
Joseph Williamson
and
John Simmons
.

JOSEPH WILLIAMSON. I am a carpenter
, in partnership with John Simmons. On the 24th of March Franks showed me a plank, which had been taken from our yard in Hackney-road
. I find the prisoner bears a very good character- I believe it is his first offence.

WILLIAM FRANKS
. I am a watchman. On the 23d of March, about two o'clock in the morning, I stopped the prisoner in Wellington-square, about three hundred yards from the prosecutor's, with this plank on his shoulder - he said it was all right; he dropped it, and ran away: he was taken on the Thursday following; I knew him before.

THOMAS WEST
. I took the prisoner.
The prisoner received an excellent character.
GUILTY. Aged 21.

Strongly recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

991.
WILLIAM MASON
,
JAMES LEGERWOOD
, and
WILLIAM HARRIS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of March , 1 counterpane, value 5s. , the goods of
William Lewis
.

WILLIAM LEWIS. I am a gardener , and live at Hammersmith
. I saw this counterpane safe between eight and nine o'clock on the 11th of March, when I came home to breakfast, and in the evening it was gone; the prisoners all live at Hammersmith, about a mile from me.

ELIZABETH LEWIS
. I saw the counterpane safe at one o'clock, when I had taken my husband's dinner - I did not see it again till Davie and I found it hanging up at Bolton's, on the 13th of March.

HANNAH WEAVING
. I saw the counterpane safe between two and three o'clock in the afternoon, hanging up.

SARAH MILWOOD
. I live at Hammersmith. About eleven o'clock on the morning the counterpane was stolen, I saw the three prisoners pass our house, towards where this counterpane was, and at four o'clock I saw them again- Mason separated from them, and went towards the back of Lewis' premises, which is about one hundred yards from our house.

ANN MILLWOOD
. I saw the prisoners pass in the morning, and return in the afternoon.

ROBERT CHAMBERS
, I live at Fulham. On the 12th of March Mason came and asked if I dealt in old rags - I said Yes; he then said it was not rags, but a counterpane, and gave it up to me in my cart; I said I did not want anything of that kind; it was in a blue handkerchief, and I took it down to Bolton's, who said he would give 4s. for it, if the man came honestly by it - Mason had asked me 5s. for it; Bolton gave me 4s., and I gave it to Mason - I did not know I was doing wrong.

WILLIAM BOLTON
. I bought the counterpane of Chambers, for 4s., and hung it at my bed-room window, as I thought it was damp.

DAVID DAVIE
. I found the counterpane at Bolton's. - I took Mason and Legerwood that evening; and Harris surrendered.
WILLIAM HELPS. On the 12th of March, about half-past ten o'clock, I saw the three prisoners pass my house together; Legerwood had a bundle under his arm, tied in a yellow handkerchief.

MASON -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

LEGERWOOD -
NOT GUILTY .

HARRIS -
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

999.
HARRIET LUFF
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of February , 2 candlesticks, value 2s.; 1 piece of lace, value 6d.; and 1 blanket, value 1s. , the goods of
James Bond
.
MR. J. ALLEY conducted the prosecution.

ANN BOND
. I am wife of James Bond, and live at Brentford
. I employed the prisoner as a char-woman - she had access to every part of the house. In February last I lost this property - I received information. and went with a search-warrant to her room; we found all these articles there.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. This lace is on a cap? A. Yes; the cap is not mine - I know the lace by the pattern - it had been on a cap of mine; here are two pieces on the cap; only one is mine - the candlesticks are broken in pieces: they were broken, but not as they are now; I found them in a basket, with some rags; I had two yards of this lace - I know the blanket by the pattern - she owes my husband some money; she said the broken brass was given her by my servant.

MR. J. ALLEY. Q. Is there any mark on the candlesticks? A. Here is a mark of some lead, where my husband tried to mend it; they were in pieces, but not broken - My sister had sent me the lace; it was exactly of this pattern.

JOSEPH DICKINSON
. I am an officer. On the 24th of March I went to the prisoner's room with the prosecutrix and others; I searched for a quarter of an hour, and by the side of the bed I found these candlesticks, tied up, in a basket - I found also the blanket and cap.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not the prosecutrix say the lace on the cap was hers? A. Yes; she did not say only part of it was hers.
JAMES BOND. I missed these candlesticks, and know them to be mine, by a mark which I made on one of them by turning a tap; and I mended this one with lead.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that the candlesticks were given to her as old metal by the prosecutrix's servant.
NOT GUILTY .

993.
HARRIET LUFF
was again indicted, for
stealing on the 24th of March , 3 table-cloths, value 20s.; 15 knives, value 3s.; 15 forks, value 3s.; and 3 towels, value 3s. , the goods of
John Surman
.

ELIZABETH SURMAN
. I am wife of John Surman - the prisoner was in my service in 1824, and was frequently at my house, once or twice a week in 1826; these articles are mine - I missed them in 1826, with a great many other things - I swear to them; there is my own writing on the table-cloth; and I know the knives and forks.

Cross-examined. Q. Has she been employed by you since 1826? A. No: she was at my house on the 24th of March, but not with my knowledge; I was present when part of the property was found in her room; some of the knives and forks were on the table - I know one knife by having broken it; I lost some of the knives in 1825.

JOSEPH DICKINSON
. I found twenty-eight duplicates in the prisoner's room, and some of these articles.

JOHN BURFORD
. I am a pawnbroker; I have a tablecloth and two towels pawned on the 17th of July last; they are marked in the prisoner's own name and her husband's, I am sure she is the person who pawned them; the prosecutrix said her name has been picked out, but there is no appearance of that; she then said she could swear to the hemming, but many females work in the same way.
Cross-examined. Q. Did she not claim a great many more things? A. Yes; I thought she would swear to all I had got.

MRS. SURMAN. Here is the place on the table-cloth where my husband's name was; it has been picked out; the name of Surman was marked in full - there were several other things at the pawnbroker's which I could have sworn to.

ELIZABETH HUGHES
. I bought these six green-handled knives and forks of the prisoner about four years ago.

ANN BOND
. I bought this table-cloth of the prisoner; it was marked B. H. L. - I never altered it.
MRS. SURMAN. I know this table-cloth; I sewed it instead of hemming it - I have another of the same pattern.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you have all these things in 1825? A. Not the small green-handled knives and forks: the prisoner came to me on the 24th of February. and left on the 1st of May, 1824; her sister then came to me and left in August, 1826, and the prisoner came to char for me that year; I never gave the sister anything; but I have given the prisoner some old bed-furniture, baby-linen, and other things; the mark has been picked out of this table-cloth; there was some of the marking cotton on it when I found it.

JURY. Q. When were the table-cloths marked? A. That I cannot say; the whole of the three were bought in 1825; the mark of the thread cannot be washed out: I missed them in 1825 - the prisoner's sister left me in disgrace in 1826: I should rather suspect her than the prisoner.

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that some ofthe things were given her by her sister, and others by the prosecutrix.
NOT GUILTY .

994.
WILLIAM WELCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. , the goods of
James Peachey
.

WILLIAM HENRY BAYFIELD
. I am shopman to James Peachey, pawnbroker , of Goswell-street
. On the afternoon of the 18th of March I observed some person as I thought unpinning the things at the door: I went round and saw the prisoner walk away, and put something into his pocket; I pursued - he ran, and threw this handkerchief out of his pocket; I took him; the handkerchief was taken up and given to me; I only lost sight of him as he turned the corner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GEORGE FULLER
. I am beadle of Christ's Hospital; I saw the prisoner in a little street turning out of Old-street, and the witness pursuing him; he caught him, and just before he came up he threw down this handkerchief, which I took up.

THOMAS WATTS
. I am a constable, and was sent for; I took the prisoner, and found two other handkerchiefs on him.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Three Months .

995.
ELLEN RYAN
and
CATHERINE GRIMES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of March , 1 blanket, value 2s.; 2 sheets, value 3s.; 1 rug, value 1s.; 1 bolster, value 2s., and 1 bed, value 5s. , the goods of
Andrew Parsons
.

ANDREW PARSONS
. On the night of the 10th of March, the watchman sent for me; I went and saw Grimes taking a bed away from an unoccupied house of mine in Maynard-street, St. Giles'; I took her to the watch-house, then came back, and met Ryan coming out of the house with the other things in a bundle; the watchman had hold of her - she threw the things down by the church, and said she would carry them no further; I had locked the house up about five o'clock that evening - they were safe then.

JOHN MURPHY
. I am a watchman. On the 10th of March, I was going by the passage of this house and saw Grimes standing by the side of this bed; I asked what she had there; she said a bed - I asked who it belanged to; she said it must belong to the person of the house; we took it into Mr. Groat - he said it belonged to Parsons: I afterwards saw Ryan, she appeared in liquor when she got near the watch-house, but not stupidly drunk.

CHARLES BENNIS
. I am a watchman. I took Ryan with a bundle containing a blanket, a rug, a pair of sheets, and a bolster.(Property produced and sworn to.)
RYAN'S Defence. I was in liquor; a woman took me up and gave me the things.
GRIMES' Defence. I was going down the stairs, and found the bed: I thought it belonged to Mr. Groat, and asked him - I know nothing of it - it lay at the stair foot.

RYAN -
GUILTY . Aged 25.

GRIMES -
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .

996.
GEORGE JACKSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of March , 5 loaves of bread, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Henry Harris
.

HENRY HARRIS. I am a baker . On the 7th of March I was out, and saw the prisoner take five loaves from my barrow; he run down Guildford-street
with them - I followed and took them from him.

HENRY GRAMMER
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner and the loaves - he said before the Magistrate that he had not eaten for two days.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined One Month .

997.
JAMES ELLIS
,
WILLIAM BOYDEN
, and
THOMAS WILLIAMS
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of February , 1 caravan, value 15l. , the goods of
Charles Henry Buttler
.

CHARLES HENRY BUTTLER. I am a stable-keeper , and live in Little Portman-street, Cavendish-square
. I had a caravan in the street, in front of my house, on Friday, the 22d of February; I saw it there at twelve o'clock at night, and in the morning it was gone - I saw part of it on the 2d of March.
Prisoner ELLIS. Q. To what part of it do you swear to? A. To the shafts, the wheel-plate, and part of the side.

FRANCIS KEYS
. I am an officer. On Friday, the 29th of February, I saw the three prisoners coming down Whitechapel in a cart: they went into a mews in Great Garden-street, Whitechapel; Ellis then got out, and the other two drove the cart into the stable; I waited about half an hour, then got Fowler - we went and found Ellis standing at the top of the Mews; we took him down to the stable, where we found the other two sitting on some straw; we handcuffed them all together; I had seen them before that day in the Mews, and knew they kept their cart there.

JAMES FOWLER
. I am an officer. I went with Keys to the stable, and found a large quantity of pieces of vans and carts, in a loft over the stable; Ellis called them his premises; I found Mr. Buttler and shewed him some parts of what I found, and he claimed them; I have not brought them here - there was a cart load altogether.

Prisoner ELLIS. Q. What did he swear to? A. Some of the iron and the shafts; he described them to me before he saw them; he said there was a hook broken underneath, and it was so; I found part of the iron in the Mews and part at McDowell's.

JOSEPH HAMMOND
. I was with the officers, and brought the things from the loft; what they have stated is correct.

REBECCA ELIZABETH McDOWELL
. My father keeps a marine store shop in Fieldgate-street, Whitechapel. On the last week in February, Ellis brought some old iron in a cart; I bought a sweep-plate and some other cartiron of him - I asked his name, he said, Ellis, and that it was his own - I broke the iron up myself, and it was put in among the other iron, and in due time it was separated - I cannot point out any part which I bought of him, except the plate; the Magistrate sent an officer to see what we had bought; I showed him what we had, and he took some away.
Prisoner ELLIS. Q. On what day of the week did I bring it? A. I believe on a Wednesday; I do not know the day of the month.

WILLIAM HARRIS
. I am an officer; I went to McDowell's, and found some iron - Mr. Buttler has seen and claimed it; but I have not brought it here.
Prisoner ELLIS. Q. What did you get there? A. A sweep-plate, two staves, and some loose iron; there were several tons of iron there.

HENRY MARSHALL
. I am a tripeman; a person resembling Ellis hired a stable of me in Great Garden-street, that is the stable the officers searched - he took it in his own name.

CHARLES WORGAN
. I am carman to Mr. Emery, of Gun-square; I met Ellis in Whitechapel - I knew him by the name of Bullen; he asked, where I was going? I said, I had nothing to do; he asked if I would go with him to sell some old iron, and he would give me some beer - I went with him to McDowell's, and took the iron; there was a round plate and some other iron.

Prisoner ELLIS. Q. What day was it? A. I believe it was Wednesday - it was the latter end of February; your mother went by the name of Bullen - I have been in your loft and saw a pair of shafts there, I think you said, you were going to build a van with them in the summer for yourself; that might be three or four weeks ago.
COURT. Q. How long was it before you went to the Magistrate? A. About a fortnight; I only judge of the time I went with him by master having nothing to do - it was towards the end of February.
Prisoner ELLIS. Q. Was not the iron sold on the Wednesday week before I was apprehended? A. I think so; I was examined on the 17th of March, and think it was on the Wednesday week before that.

MR. BUTTLER. I saw the shafts, they are mine, and so is the sweep-plate, and some pieces of the cart I can swear to; I know the shafts by some plates and some hooks on them - I had had the van about two years; I bought it - it has been mended once, and I also had done something to it myself; I had put some plates on the shaft, and there are several parts of my mending which I can swear to.
Prisoner ELLIS. Q. Did you ever take the sweepplate off? A. No, but I have looked at it many times.

ELLIS'S Defence. He is a false swearing man, it is not his iron; I dealt in iron, and sold some there before - I was first examined on the 29th of February, and then Worgan said it was the Wednesday week before.(See Fifth Day.)

ELLIS -
GUILTY . Aged 24.

BOYDEN -
NOT GUILTY .

WILLIAMS -
NOT GUILTY .

998.
SARAH DAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of March , 1 oz. and 5 dwts. of silver, value 6s. , the goods of
Clement Cheese
.

CLEMENT CHEESE. I am a silversmith , and live in Clerkenwell
, the prisoner was in my service. On the 1st of March I found I was deficient in my stock, and on the 3d I was deficient again; I told her on the Sunday that I was deficient, and I would know who it was - on the Monday I told her I was short again, and I would see in her box; she said, she was never called a thief before - I said, if she had nothing of mine, she could not object to my seeing her box; she hesitated - I went up stairs with my errand-boy; she opened her box and took out a small paper parcel, which she tried to put into her pocket - the boy stopped her hand, and we found it was this piece of silver; I told the boy to empty out the box, and we found some more silver - she fell on her knees and begged forgiveness; here is an ancient coin among it, which I know well, and a piece of an ingot; she only lived eleven days with me, and came from the office in Holborn.(Property produced and sworn to.)

BENJAMIN DUKE
. I am Mr. Cheese's errand-boy; I saw the silver found in the prisoner's box - she asked forgiveness.

WILLIAM BROWN EDWARDS
. I am an officer, and took her in charge.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

999.
WILLIAM HATTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of March , 1 knife, value 9d.; 3 shillings; 1 six-pence; and 104 farthings , the property of
Thomas James
.

ANN JAMES
. I am wife of Thomas James; he keeps a shop in Pitfield-street, Hoxton
- On the 12th of March, I was in the parlour and heard money jingle, and presently I heard it again; I then looked towards the shop, and saw something black, which I thought was the dog; but presently I saw a head - I called my husband, who was in bed in the parlour - he went and took the prisoner in the shop. I had seen 3s. 6d. in the till shortly before - I found the till open. and the box containing the silver taken out - I found the money under a mat behind the counter; he had got a knife up his sleeve.

ESTHER BLATCHLEY
. I was at work with the prosecutrix; I went into the shop, and served the prisoner with nuts; I opened the till then, and saw some silver and farthings in it - he went out - I went into the room and sat down - we afterwards heard money jink twice; we went out, and I saw the prisoner behind the counter; 3s. 6d. was found under the mat; the farthings lay at a little distance; nobody came into the shop after him; he is a sweep.

GEORGE WILMOT
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Confined Three Months .

1000.
JOHN M'GINNIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of March , 1 plane, value 2s.; one oil-stone, value 2s.; and 1 chisel, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
James Howting
; 2 saws, value 7s.; 1 plane, value 3s.; and 1 hammer, value 1s., the goods of
Nathaniel Raven
; two saws, value 5s.; 1 stock and 6 bits, value 5s.; 1 plane, value 2s.; 1 chisel, value 6d.; 3 gouges, value 6d.; 2 files, value 6d.; 1 screw-driver, value 6d.; and 1 pair of dividers, value 1s. the goods of
William James
.

JAMES HOWTING. I am a carpenter . On the 27th of March I was working at the new buildings, at the London Docks
; Raven and James were also working there. On the evening of the 26th I left my tools safe in the corner, next the water-side, and next morning I missed some tools; these are them.

NATHANIEL RAVEN. I was working at the Docks - I lost two saws, a plane, and other tools, which I left safe on the night of the 26th; I had locked them up in a place, but the lock was wrenched off - I know nothing of the prisoner.
WILLIAM JAMES. I was working at the Docks, andlost a quantity of tools, which I had left safe the night before; I have not found them all.

WILLIAM MITCHELL. I am a Bow-street patrol; I took the prisoner on the morning of the 29th, as he was turning into a pawnbroker's shop with a saw down his coat; I asked where he got it - he said he bought it of a man in Rosemary-lane; I took him to the Docks - James claimed the saw; he told me where his lodgings were: I went and found the other tools, stated in the indictment - I found forty-seven duplicates on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I picked up some tools, and bought the others.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Transported for Seven Years .

1001.
JOHN DEVINE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of March , 1 door, value 16s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Hall
.
ELIZABETH HALL. I am a widow . On the 12th of March I lost this door from an unfinished house, which my husband was building before he died - I know it by some marks on it.

THOMAS TUCHIN
. I am a grocer, and live in Whiteconduit-fields. On the 12th of March, the prisoner passed my shop-door towards the prosecutrix's house, and in about three minutes he came back with the door on his shoulder; two other men were with him; I overtook him with it - he said a gentleman had employed him to carry it to the Angel; the other two men went away when they saw me pursuing him - he said he did not know the gentleman.

THOMAS HUNT
. I went with Tuchin; I saw the door was gone from the house - we pursued and took the prisoner with it - he said, a man, whom he never saw before, was to give him sixpence to carry it to the Angel.

EDWARD PALMER
. I am a Bow-street patrol. I came up and took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I was out of employ, and accepted of this job; I did not know the door was stolen.
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Confined Three Months .
FOURTH DAY. MONDAY, APRIL 14.
First Middlesex Jury. - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1002.
GEORGE CULLEY
and
THOMAS FAGAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of February , 1 cask, value 8s. , the goods of
Thomas Harris
.
MR. ALLEY conducted the prosecution.

ROBERT DUKE
. I am an officer of Hatton-garden. On the 28th of February I was in company with Bassett and Lloyd, near the house of Linton, at Islington-green; he is a retailer of table-beer, what is called a pinman; I saw the two prisoners about six o'clock in the evening, come there, and Culley had a firkin on his shoulder; they were walking in company together; I should think they were a mile and a half, or two miles from Mr. Harris'; he lives in the Hampstead-road; they went up the gateway to Linton's brewery, and set the cask down at Linton's door - they then went to a workshop in the same yard, next door to Linton's, made some inquiry, and then returned up the yard; I went to them, and asked what they had left the cask there for - they appeared confused, and I said, "What business had you to leave that cask there?" they said they had found it in Smithfield, and were going to take it home- I think it was Fagan who said he picked it up, and Culley said he was assisting him to carry it; it was a small cask, and did not require two men to carry it; I took them in charge, and fetched the cask from Linton's door.

ANDREW LLOYD
. I am an officer, and was with Duke- his evidence is correct; here is the cask - it has "T. Harris, Hampstead-road," on it, in large letters.
THOMAS BASSETT. I am employed by brewers to watch their property. I was with the officers when this cask was taken.

THOMAS HARRIS. I am a brewer , and live in Hampstead-road
. Fagan has lived in my service, and knew my premises well. This is my cask - it is worth 8s. 6d. I have lost a considerable number.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Fagan had been in your employ? A. Occasionally; Culley was not in my service - we loose casks in a variety of ways.
MR. ALLEY. Q. Do you ever allow a cask to be sold? A. No; that is a fixed rule in the trade.

THOMAS BISHOP
. I live near Linton. The prisoners came to me on the evening in question, and asked if Linton was within - I said I believed he was; they went into the yard, returned, and said he was not; Fagan asked if I knew what public-house he used; I said I believed he was at the Fox, at the corner.
CULLEY'S Defence. This man asked me to help him.
FAGAN'S Defence. I picked up the cask.

FAGAN -
GUILTY . Aged 37.

CULLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 44.
Transported for Seven Years .

1003.
THOMAS FAGAN
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of February
, 3 casks, value 24s. , the goods of
Thomas Harris
; and
SAMUEL LINTON
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, knowing them to have been stolen .

THOMAS PERRY
. I am drayman to the prisoner Linton, who carries on business at Islington-green; he sells small casks of table-beer - I have seen Fagan there several times, selling casks. One day about the 30th of November, he brought a porter cask, marked "T. Harris, Hampstead-road;" he saw Linton, and said, "I have brought you one of your casks:" they walked out together, as if they were going to have a glass; Linton used to pay 2s. for them; I saw no money pass that day. About December Fagan came and sat a cask down - Linton came and asked if I had any money - I gave him 6s.; he gave Fagan 2s. for it - it was marked with Mr. Harris' name; Fagan came to me when I was washing casks in the yard, and said, "Is it not a shame, the old man does not allow more than 2s. for the casks - he sells them for 4s. 6d."
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How long have you lived with Linton? A. Four or five months; I left last Saturday week: before that I lived with Mr. Mitchell, of Hackney.

Q. Were you discharged for dishonesty? A. I am not compelled to read my life to you; I was discharged once: I had been about three weeks with Linton when Fagan brought the first cask - I did not inform Mr. Harris of it.

I went-to Brewer's: Hall about February, and told Bassett, for I thought it high time it was stopped. I never bought a cask - I warned Linton of it several times. I have been desired several times to fetch casks for him, but would not do it.
COURT. Q. You have been in the trade a long time? A. Yes; I believe the casks cost 8s. each, new - they are better for being new.
Mr. ALLEY declined proceeding any further in this case.
NOT GUILTY .

1003.
SAMUEL LINTON
was again indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 28th of February , of a certain evil disposed person, 1 barrel, value 15s., the goods of
William Simpson
, which had been by the said evil-disposed person stolen, he, the said Samuel Linton, well knowing it to have been stolen, against the Statute, &c.

ROBERT DUKE. On the 28th of February, I went with Bassett and Lloyd to Linton's premises, at Islingtongreen; I found about one hundred and fifty casks there, or more; I took away one barrel, one kilderkin, and two firkins - I took them to the Red Lion public-house, Islingtongreen, and saw them locked up in a coal-cellar - I desired that no person might have them but myself, or Lloyd; when we fetched them away, I found part of the head of the barrel, where the name had been, chipped off - I had made no alteration in it; one head was out when I found it at Linton's.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was Linton present when you took them away? A. Yes; I did not ask his leave.

ANDREW LLOYD
. I am an officer of Hatton-garden. I assisted in taking the casks from Linton's; when I saw them next day they were in a different state - Linton was not present then; I asked him when we found where he had got them; he gave no answer.

JOSEPH MASON PAUL
. I am a cooper. On the 28th or 29th of February, the prisoner came to my shop, and told me to bring my tools; I went with him to the Red Lion, Islington-green; he went into the bar, and spoke to the landlord; the boy got the key, and went into the cellar - the casks were brought out to me in the skittle-ground; he told me to take the two little marks out - they were scratch marks; the same as we mark all our heads with - that makes the wood look clean; I never did a job for him before.

COURT. Q. Look at this cask, is it the one out of which you took two marks? A. It is; one head was out then; I asked him if it was his own; he said Yes, and told me to take them down to the shop, and cobble them.

Cross-examined. Q. What do you know the cask by? A. By the top; I know no mark on it - I do not swear positively to it; I have known Linton twelve or fourteen years, but did no business for him; he did not ask me to do this privately.
MR. ALLEY. Q. What time of day was this? A. Between six and seven o'clock in the morning of the 29th of February - he said he had bought them.

JAMES HARDING
. I am servant at the Red Lion. Paul had the same casks to cut as the officers brought - they brought three; Paul left them in the skittle-ground, and the officers fetched them from the ground; when the marks were cut out, the prisoner asked me to disguise the places where they had been cut out; I was to get some dirty water and mud, and put on it; he said he would give me 6d. - I did not do it; they were fetched away in two or three hours.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you the key of the cellar? A. I got it from my master; he did not hesitate about giving it to me; I told him Linton wanted it - my master was not there when they were brought, and did not know of their being stolen.

THOMAS BASSETT
. I am inspector to the brewers. I went to Linton's, on the 28th of February, with the officers; I saw this cask in the brewhouse; we took it to the public-house with others - there were about one hundred and fifty casks there with the names chipped out - there were about three hundred casks in all - this one was without a head; I went again on the 21st of March, and found the head in the brewhouse, under the same roof as the cask was - I produce it.
Cross-examined. Q. Is Mr. Simpson's name on it? A. Yes; here is "Simpson, Lambeth," on the head - it was stowed away.

WILLIAM SIMPSON
. I am a brewer, and live at Lambeth. I have lost a great many casks of all descriptions - I never sold one; this head belongs to the cask produced, and is mine; another mark on the other head has been partly scraped out - it is worth about 1l.
Cross-examined. Q. How many other persons are there of your name in the trade? A. Not one.
GUILTY . Aged 68.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1004.
WILLIAM FARMER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of February , 1 cask, value 6s. , the goods of
Job West
and
James West
.

ROBERT DUKE
. I am an officer. On the 28th of February, as I stood at the corner of Lloyd's-row, I saw the prisoner with a man, named Bateman, whom I know to be a receiver; while I was talking to Bateman the prisoner came up: Bateman called to him, "Farmer, Farmer;" I stopped him, and insisted that he should not say any thing- the prisoner went, and put down a cask at Bateman's door; I went to him, and said, "What did you leave that there for?" he said he lived with Mr. West, and that the dray was coming presently - I secured him.
JOB WEST. I am in partnership with James West; the prisoner was never in our employ - I never directed our dray to call at Bateman's - we have lost several casks.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Was the prisoner with your drayman that day? A. No; my dray was out.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was with the man all day, and picked up this cask - I did not know it was Mr. West's; I did not know Bateman; I was going to take the cask to my lodgings, and thought I would go to the drayman next day, and give it him, as I used to go round with him.
GUILTY . Aged 44.
Transported for Seven Years .

1005.
WILLIAM BULL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of February , 107 squares of glass, value 20l., and 1 box, value 6s. , the goods of
Thomas Kinner
.

SECOND COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
Henry Brooks
.
MR. ALLEY conducted the prosecution.

HENRY BROOKS. I live in the Strand, and am a window glass cutter . On the 26th of January, I received an order to send these goods to Mr.
Joseph Cooper
, at Reading - there was some stained glass among it. I sent it on the 4th of February, by Ford, to Kinner's waggon.

GEORGE FORD
. I am Mr. Brooks' servant, and took the box on the 4th of February, I delivered it to Kinner's waggon.

THOMAS KINNER. I am part owner of the Reading waggon . I received this box, and loaded it in the hind part of the waggon; which I drove, and saw it safe at the further end of Brentford. I missed it when I arrived at Hounslow; the cords had been cut to get it.

JOHN SELLS
. I am a carpenter, and live at Kensington. The prisoner is a stable-keeper , and lived over Mr. Dyer's stables, at Kensington; on the morning of the 16th of February, (as near as I can judge) he came to me in the front of my house, and asked if I knew anybody in the building line, who wanted any window-glass. I said I had a house to glaze, and I would look at it - he said if I would call in about half an hour, he would shew it to me; that he had it to sell for a poor man who was in the Bench- he called in about half an hour and we went up to his room over the stable. I saw Matthews in the room, looking over the glass; I did not examine it, for I was afraid of breaking it; it looked very good. Matthews said, if he had all the money in the world, he would not give more than 6l. for it; the prisoner was in the room at that time, I think. I said nothing to him about the price - I never offered him any price; he never asked what I would give for it.
Q. Did you ever propose any price to the prisoner? A. Never; till I left the money in the publican's hands; and said if he would take 5l. or five guineas for it, I would have it.

Q. How came you to leave that message with him? A. I was obliged to go to town - I gave him four sovereigns, and asked him to lend me 25s. I got the glass out of the room on the Sunday morning afterwards; I carried it home, and had it glazed - I bought nothing but plain glass of him; the prisoner had mentioned no price in my hearing.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did not the prisoner tell you he had it from a person at Kensington, who had it from a man in the Bench? A. No; I had known the prisoner for about a fortnight before.

JOHN MATTHEWS
. I am a painter and glazier. On the 16th of February, the prisoner told me he had some glass to dispose of, for a person in trouble, and asked if I could get a customer, or buy it myself; he would let me have it reasonable - I went, and while I was measuring it, Sells came; I should call it second glass. I saw some orange coloured, and some ground glass there - there was about 120 square feet altogether; the largest square I saw was twenty-two inches by fifteen.

Cross-examined. Q. Did the prisoner keep a liverystable, in Earl-street? A. Yes; I know one Cox - I do not know where he is, or whether he has absconded; the prisoner did not tell me it came from Cox.

JAMES JONES
. I am a publican. I paid the prisoner five guineas, which Sells left for him; he did not say it was for glass.

JOSEPH DYER
. I am a publican; the prisoner lived in some premises of mine - I took him a pot of hot one morning, and saw a quantity of glass of different sizes; I did not notice any coloured. I asked where he got it; he said he had it to sell for one Rodman, who had bought it at a sale, at Hammersmith and left it for him to take care of, as he could not take it home; and if he got a customer he might sell it for him - the prisoner rented a stable of me, and, I believe, deals in horses.
Cross-examined. Q. Was the glass concealed? A. No; I am sure he mentioned Rodman's name.

ROBERT DUKE
. I am an officer, and apprehended the prisoner; I said I had come about some glass - he said he had none. I said "No; it was some you sold to Sells;" he said he had sold some to Sells - and that he had it from a person who was now in the Bench. I asked his name, he declined answering any more questions.
NOT GUILTY .

1006.
ANTHONY WEST
&
THOMAS SINGFIELD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of February , 7 live tame rabbits, price 20s.; 3 live tame ducks, price 7s.; and 1 live tame drake, price 3s. ; the property of
AEneas Barkly
.
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

JAMES AMBROSE
. I am a gardner to Mr. Eneas Barkly; he lives at Highbury Grove
; he has a farm-yard , where he keeps rabbits and poultry. On Sunday afternoon, on the 24th of February, at half-past four o'clock, I saw the poultry all safe, and next morning, at a quarter-past six, I missed seven rabbits, three ducks, and a drake; I have seen two of the rabbits since in Cox's custody; they were taken from a butch in a shed, which was not locked; the ducks were all white and very large, the drake was the largest ever seen.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did your master have hand-bills printed describing them? A. Yes; I cannot read. I can swear to one rabbit by a slit in the ear; they had black spots on their faces and all over them.
MR. BODKIN. Q. How long has your master had these rabbits? A. About two years; I attended to them.

JOHN COX
. I am gardener to Mr. Barkly. On the 24th of February (Sunday) these rabbits were stolen; I went to the pales about seven o'clock in the morning, and saw some footsteps; I noticed one particularly - there was one particular nail in the fore part of the heel-piece, and I traced the marks from the premises, over one field, to Hornsey-lane, about a mile towards Holloway; I do not know the prisoner - I have seen two rabbits here, which I am sure are master's.
Cross-examined. Q. Is this one of the hand-bills? A. Yes? I believe the rabbits are not correctly described, as to the colour.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Were you present when any shoes were fitted to the marks on the ground? A. Yes; they fitted exactly.

EDWARD JOHNSON
. I am headborough of Islington. In consequence of information, I went to Selley's house, on the 27th of February, and received from him two live rabbits, one duck and one drake dead - I gave the rabbitsto Cox; I went on the same day to No. 12, Brand-street, Holloway, where the two prisoners live - I saw West, and asked him where Singfield was - he said he was not at home; I searched the house, and under the bed found a lot of white feathers in a flat, and then found a lot of feathers in a bag - there were about as many feathers as would cover four ducks; I left, and went there again, and saw West without his shoes; there was a pair of shoes by the side of where he sat; Price, who was with me, took them up, and I looked at them; Price said he thought they corresponded with the foot marks; we made him put them on, and took him away with them; I went next morning to Mr. Barkly's premises with the shoes, and examined the foot-marks in two or three places in the shrobbery, and fitted the shoes; they corresponded exactly with the marks. In consequence of information I went to Woburn, in Bedfordshire, and found Singfield; he saw me and ran away; I followed, and found him at Bow-brickhill, in Buckinghamshire; he was then at dinner - he said, "All you have against me is selling them; not stealing them" - and when on the coach, he said he should not have been drawn into if it had not been for Tom.

Cross-examined. Q. You have known Singfield some time? A. Yes; I never knew anything against him, but I have heard something - the ducks found were plucked. all but the heads; the drake was very large - we found some cock and hen feathers - it was on Thursday that I fitted the shoes; I think it had rained one night since the Sunday, but am not certain.

JAMES PRICE
. I am an officer of Islington. On Monday morning, the 25th, I went to Mr. Barkly's and saw the footmarks; I went on Thursday and fitted the shoes; I noticed one particular nail in front of the heel, which fitted the marks exactly - West resisted being taken.
Cross-examined. Q. Was not he in bed? A. No. There had been no rain from the Sunday till the Thursday - I came up at night - there is a border round the shrobbery: the marks were very plain there.
COURT. Q. Did it appear to you that two persons had been there? A. I only saw the footmark of one person.

SAMUEL SELLEY
. I bought two rabbits and two ducks of Singfield, on Monday the 25th of February, and gave the same to the officers.

JAMES PRICE
. I gave a description of the rabbits as I had received it from Cox, and no other description was given for the bills.

WEST -
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

SINGFIELD -
NOT GUILTY .

1007.
ISAAC EVANS
was indicted for
embezzlement .
MR. ALLEY conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS STARLING
. I am an engraver , and have a plan of the parish of St. Mary Islington - the prisoner was in my employ; he was to go round and shew this engraving; some of them were 5s., and some 16s., according to the size - he was to come to me every night, to state the result of his day's labour, and pay the money to me - he took a receipt-book with him and when he sold any, he was to give a receipt, and write the name on the margin of the book - he never accounted to me for monies received from Mr. Walker, Mr. Fieldhouse, and Cooper - he said they were out, and he was to call again on them.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How did you pay him? A. By a commission on every subscriber he obtained; and he was occasionally employed in writing for me; I considered him as my servant; he received the money at the time he obtained the signatures and was then to have his commission, that was, before he delivered the plans - I have no recollection of having described him as my agent; there was not a debtor and creditor account between us.

Q. Did you ever call on him to become a witness for you at any trial? A. I wished him to become a witness about a fortnight before I made this discovery; which was on the 28th of March, and not before; he was to be witness about a dozen of these plans, which he had delivered to a shopkeeper.
Q. Did he refuse to become a witness? A. The case never came on; he refused by engaging to go to Wales - I knew he was going before that - he was examined four times on this charge.

Q. Did you not, after the first examination, apply to make it up? A. No: I should have been glad to have done it, and was applied to about it by Mr. Morley; I advanced him money from time to time, as he stated that he was very poor.

JAMES WALKER
. I was to have a plan from the prosecutor; I paid the prisoner 5s, for it; it was since Christmas, but I cannot say when.

CHARLES FIELDHOUSE
. I ordered a plan of the prisoner, and paid him 5s. about the 11th of February.

WILLIAM COOPER
. I bought this plan of the prisoner, about the first week in February, and paid him 16s.

THOMAS STARLING
. These sums have never been paid to me; they are entered in the receipt-book, and he has written there that he was to call again.

Prisoner's Defence. I called on Mr. Starling on the Friday before I was taken, and said I had used about 2l. of his money, as he owed me about 6l.; I had done so repeatedly before and he had consented to it; but on that day he had an action pending - he sent for an officer, and detained me; he has been with me frequently in prison, and trifled with my feelings very much.

FOSTER EDWARD ABEL
. I am articled clerk to Mr. Bean - I have received two letters from the prosecutor, in which he describes the prisoner as his agent - I have not preserved the letters.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1008.
SOPHIA MATILDA CAMERON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of February , 1 ring, value 4s. , the goods of
Michael McGoverin
.

SARAH McGOVERIN
. I am the wife of Michael Mc Goverin; we live in Union-street. The prisoner lodged with us for fourteen or fifteen weeks - I lost a ring, on the 21st of February, from a wine glass on the mantelshelf; I asked her about it several times, and desired her to give it up, but she constantly denied having it - I missed a twist gold ring about a month after; and while I went for an officer she ran away; she was afterwards taken; and the duplicate of the first ring found on her.

THOMAS PERRING
. I am an officer. The prisoner wasgiven into my custody - I found three duplicates on her; one for this ring, pawned for 1s. on the 23d of February; the prosecutrix redeemed it; the pawnbroker is not here; the prisoner said she had pawned it in company with the prosecutrix's husband.
Prisoner's Defence. Her husband sent me to pawn it, as he wanted money.
MICHAEL M'GOVERIN. I never anthorized her to pawn it or anything else - I went out with her sometimes.
NOT GUILTY .

1009.
JOHN HALL
and
THOMAS GRAY
were indicted for
stealing on the 22d of March , 1 silver watch, value 25s.; 1 metal key, value 2d.; and 1 metal seal, value 4d., the goods of
Joseph Mayes
, from his person .

JOHN MAYES. I am a watchman , of Piccadilly. On the 2d of March I was at the ruins of the Brunswick Theatre
, with my wife and son, between twelve and one o'clock in the day - the crowd pressed very heavily on me, and I found my right arm confined to my side; it was done intentionally; I missed my watch from my fob as soon as my arm was at liberty - Gray was as close to my right side as he could be; I did not notice Hall till afterwards; they were both taken into custody while I was there: I am certain my watch was safe when I entered the crowd.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was there not a moving crowd there? A. A gig came by which made them move.

GEORGE WADDINGTON
. I was at the Brunswick Theatre; there was a great rush; I heard the prosecutor call out, "Don't hurt my wife;" I saw Gray had got hold of the prosecutor's coat on his right hand side, and his other hand was under the coat: Hall pushed against him close to the prosecutor, and in a moment Newton called out"He has got it" - I looked and saw the watch fall; it dropped as if from Gray, but I did not see it in any one's hand; there was a crowd at the time, in consequence of some vehicle going by.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. There was a rush backwards and forwards? A. Yes; we were all pushed against the prosecutor.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Is it remarkable for a man to lay hold of another, to save himself from falling? A. He had hold of his coat, and the prosecutor called out, "Don't hurt my wife."

JAMES NEWTON
. I was with Waddington, and saw Hall with his hands in a direction towards the prosecutor; he gave Gray something, which he put into his right-hand trousers pocket - Hall was in front of him, and Gray close at his right-hand side; I collared Gray directly; he put his hand into his pocket, and took something out, and the pocket with it; and in struggling I saw this watch in the kennel, between his legs; I did not see it fall - it was something small that Hall gave Gray.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you hear Waddington examined? A. Yes; we were all pushed together; Hall was pressed violently against the prosecutor- he could not prevent it; there were above a hundred persons there: Hall was hardly master of his hands.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. And yet you saw Gray put something into his pocket, and take it out again? A. Yes - there were several people pushing against us; I did not hear the watch fall; I first saw it on the ground; Gray had not been pushed about at that time- I kept him pretty steady.

WILLIAM McNAB
. I went to the Theatre, and in two or three minutes there was a strong rush; Newton sang out, "George, he has got it;" I looked round, and saw the watch falling close to Gray, just by his feet; I turned round, and saw Hall on my right. I did not see the prosecutor till next day.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. What are you? A. A journeyman baker; I saw the watch falling. I assisted to secure Gray.

PHILIP WAINWRIGHT
. I am an engraver. I was present, and saw a rush; I met Waddington, and saw Hall going through the crowd; I saw Gray putting something into his pocket, and heard Newton say, "George, he has got it;" I had seen Hall do nothing but press close to the prosecutor - his hands were towards him; I looked down, and saw the watch near the gutter. Waddington took Gray; I assisted to take Hall - I saw Newton pick the watch up.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Would it not be natural for Hall to put out his hands when there was a rush? A. Yes.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. You did not see Gray's hand on the prosecutor? A. No.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GRAY'S Defence. I am innocent.

GRAY -
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .

HALL -
NOT GUILTY .

1010.
STEPHEN CABLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of March , 2 seals, value 20s.; 1 watch-key, value 6s., and 1 ring, value 4s. , the goods of
Samuel Tyso
.

SAMUEL TYSO. I am a groom , and live with Mr. Lyons, in Holborn. On the evening of the 5th of March I was at the Green Man, public-house, in Bond-street; the prisoner, who is an acquaintance of mine, came in; we went home together to my lodging in Oxford-street
- we slept together, and the next morning the prisoner got up, and went out; I missed my seals and key about half an hour after he was gone; I found him on the evening of the 7th of March, and asked him about my seals - he said he had never touched them: we went together to the Green Man, and there I gave charge of him; I saw the seals found in his watch pocket, under his own watch; they were not on his watch-chain.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Were you not both servants out of place? A. Yes; I got into a squabble with some girls, and went to the watch-house; the prisoner said he had advanced 2s. for me. After the seals were found he said he took them merely out of a frolic; I have known him five or six months - he has been an honest good lad.

JOHN LACY
. I am a beadle. I took the prisoner, and said to him, "If you know anything of these seals, give them up;" he said he knew nothing about them; I searched him, and found them in his fob.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Two Months .

1011.
JOHN RICHARDS
was indicted for
stealing, onthe 8th of April , 1 cloak, value 20s. , the goods of
William Sandford Hall
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 33.
Strongly recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor; and a gentleman engaged to take him into his service.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1012.
JOSEPH CANNON
and
JOHN LANE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of April , 2 lbs. weight of cheese, value 1s. 4d. , the goods of
Christopher Tutin
.

WILLIAM WHITTINGHAM. I am an officer. On the 1st of April I saw the two prisoners together in the Strand, they passed the window of Mr. Christopher Tutin's shop, in the Strand
- he is a cheesemonger . I saw Cannon take a piece of cheese, which he gave to Lane; he passed the shop, turned short round, and took another piece, which he gave to Lane, who put them both into his apron, and wrapped it round his body - I took them both.
Prisoner LANE. He took us into the shop, and asked how many pieces of cheese they had lost, they said one. Witness. They looked afterwards, and said there were two.

CANNON -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

LANE -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1013.
JAMES WILKINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of March , certain fixtures, viz. 2 sash-frames, value 4s.; 3 sash-weights, value 1s., and 24 panes of glass, value 10s., of, and belonging to
Daniel Dyball
, and fixed to a certain building of his; against the Statute .

DANIEL DYBALL. I am owner of a house in Type-court, Type-street, Grub-street
; I saw it on Sunday morning the 9th of March I think - it was all safe, and the sashes were all right; I had not been there before for some time - on the Monday or Tuesday night two officers came and gave me information; I went down and missed the sashes, here are some parts of them - I have fitted them and they appear to be part of the sashes; I had employed the prisoner occasionally, and he was a tenant of mine.

THOMAS BREEDON
. I am a carman. On Tuesday night the 11th of March, I was in bed, and was knocked up by some one who said there were thieves in Mr. Dyball's house next door to me; I went with Mr. Bee and examined the premises - we saw a parcel of old sashes broken, which had been taken from the second floor - we went round to Dyball's; he came with us and searched the premises; on coming away, I said, I had seen the prisoner on the Sunday, taking out some at the back premises - Dyball said, "He lives up here;" we went up to his apartment - he was in bed; they went in and I staid outside - they brought out this old frame and glass which we took to the watch-house; I did not hear the prisoner say anything.
Prisoner. Q. Is there not a thoroughfare through the empty house to mine? A. It ought to be kept fastened, but I have seen it open.

JOHN BEE
